ai-snp3.7:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Northern Āpaṇas together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Northern Āpaṇas named Āpaṇa.
ai-snp3.7:1.4_0: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
ai-snp3.7:1.6_0: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
ai-snp3.7:1.7_0: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
ai-snp3.7:1.8_0: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
ai-snp3.7:1.9_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
ai-snp3.7:2.1_0: So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-snp3.7:2.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
ai-snp3.7:2.3_0: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching,
ai-snp3.7:2.4_0: Then he said to the Buddha,
ai-snp3.7:2.5_0: “Please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
ai-snp3.7:2.6_0: When he said this, the Buddha said to Keṇiya,
ai-snp3.7:2.7_0: “The Sangha is large, Keṇiya. There are twelve hundred and fifty monks. Moreover, you have confidence in the brahmins.”
ai-snp3.7:3.2_0: “Even though the mendicant Saṅgha was sixteen hundred and fifty mendicants,
ai-snp3.7:3.3_0: Would you and the Sangha of monks please accept a meal from me tomorrow?”
ai-snp3.7:3.5_0: “The Sangha is large, Keṇiya. There are twelve hundred and fifty monks. Moreover, you have confidence in the brahmins.”
ai-snp3.7:4.1_0: and a third time Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
ai-snp3.7:4.2_0: “Even though the mendicant Saṅgha was sixteen hundred and fifty mendicants,
ai-snp3.7:4.3_0: Would you and the Sangha of monks please accept a meal from me tomorrow?”
ai-snp3.7:4.4_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-snp3.7:4.5_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and went to his own hermitage.
ai-snp3.7:4.5_1: and after approaching he addressed his friends,
ai-snp3.7:4.7_0: I have invited the ascetic Gotama for a meal on the following day.
ai-snp3.7:4.8_0: Please help me with the preparations.”
ai-snp3.7:4.9_0: “Yes, sir,” they replied. Some dug ovens, some chopped wood, some washed dishes, some set out a water jar, and some spread out seats.
ai-snp3.7:4.10_0: Meanwhile, Keṇiya set up the pavilion himself.
ai-snp3.7:5.1_0: Now at that time the brahmin Sela was residing in Āpaṇa. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philology and grammar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. And he was teaching three hundred students to recite the hymns.
ai-snp3.7:6.1_0: Now at that time Keṇiya was devoted to Sela.
ai-snp3.7:6.2_0: Then Sela, while going for a walk escorted by the three hundred students, approached Keṇiya’s hermitage.
ai-snp3.7:6.3_0: He saw some matted-hair ascetic tanks.
ai-snp3.7:6.3_1: Some prepared the seats, while some spread out a seat, some portioned themselves in the pavilion.
ai-snp3.7:6.5_0: “Keṇiya, is your son or daughter being married? Or are you setting up a big sacrifice? Or has King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha been invited for tomorrow’s meal?”
ai-snp3.7:7.1_0: The merchant replied, “I’m not preparing for a marriage, nor have I invited King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha together with the army.
ai-snp3.7:7.2_0: Rather, I am setting up a big sacrifice.
ai-snp3.7:7.3_0: The ascetic Gotama has gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
ai-snp3.7:7.6_0: He has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal together with the Sangha of monks.”
ai-snp3.7:8.2_0: “It’s rare in the world to become a Buddha,
ai-snp3.7:8.3_0: The thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
ai-snp3.7:8.4_0: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch.
ai-snp3.7:8.5_0: He has the following seven treasures:
ai-snp3.7:8.6_0: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.
ai-snp3.7:8.7_0: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
ai-snp3.7:8.8_0: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
ai-snp3.7:8.9_0: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.
ai-snp3.7:8.10_0: And where is Master Gotama at present?”
ai-snp3.7:9.1_0: When he said this, Keṇiya pointed with his right arm and said,
ai-snp3.7:9.2_0: “There, Mister Sela, at that line of blue forest.”
ai-snp3.7:9.3_0: Then Sela together with three hundred students went to the Buddha.
ai-snp3.7:9.6_0: For the Buddhas are intimidating, like a lion living alone.
ai-snp3.7:9.7_0: When I’m consulting with the ascetic Gotama, don’t interrupt.
ai-snp3.7:9.8_0: how can I wait until I’ve finished breaking up?”
ai-snp3.7:10.1_0: Then Sela the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-snp3.7:10.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
ai-snp3.7:10.3_0: and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.
ai-snp3.7:10.4_0: He saw all of them except for two,
ai-snp3.7:10.6_0: whether the private parts are retracted, and the largeness of the tongue.
ai-snp3.7:11.2_0: “This brahmin Sela sees all the marks except for two,
ai-snp3.7:11.4_0: whether the private parts are retracted, and the largeness of the tongue.”
ai-snp3.7:11.5_0: The Buddha used his psychic power to will that Sela would see his retracted private parts.
ai-snp3.7:11.6_0: Then the Buddha, having winnowed his ears and nose, and both surrounding them with both pearls. He then sprinkled the tongue, and lifted them up above the intermediate directions.
ai-snp3.7:12.2_0: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.
ai-snp3.7:12.3_0: But I don’t know whether or not he is an awakened one.
ai-snp3.7:12.4_0: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the teachers of teachers, said:
ai-snp3.7:12.5_0: ‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas reveal themselves when praised.’
ai-snp3.7:12.6_0: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
ai-snp3.7:12.7_0: Then Sela extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
ai-snp3.7:13.2_0: you’re radiant, handsome, lovely to behold;
ai-snp3.7:13.4_0: with teeth so white; you’re strong.
ai-snp3.7:15.1_0: Your eyes are clear, your face is fair,
ai-snp3.7:15.3_0: In the midst of the Saṅgha of ascetics,
ai-snp3.7:16.1_0: You’re a mendicant fine to see,
ai-snp3.7:16.4_0: what do you want with the ascetic life?
ai-snp3.7:17.1_0: You’re fit to be a king,
ai-snp3.7:17.2_0: a wheel-turning monarch, chief of charioteers,
ai-snp3.7:18.2_0: let us go to your hearts.
ai-snp3.7:18.3_0: King Okkāka, the lord of the earth,
ai-snp3.7:18.4_0: as king of kings, lord of men!”
ai-snp3.7:19.3_0: the supreme king of the teaching.
ai-snp3.7:19.4_0: By the teaching I roll forth the wheel
ai-snp3.7:20.3_0: the supreme king of the teaching.
ai-snp3.7:21.2_0: the disciple who follows the Teacher’s way?
ai-snp3.7:21.4_0: of the teaching you rolled forth?”
ai-snp3.7:22.1_0: “By me the wheel was rolled forth,”
ai-snp3.7:22.4_0: Sāriputta, taking after the Realized One,
ai-snp3.7:23.1_0: I have known what should be known,
ai-snp3.7:23.2_0: and developed what should be developed,
ai-snp3.7:23.3_0: and given up what should be given up:
ai-snp3.7:23.4_0: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.
ai-snp3.7:25.1_0: For those in the world who are rare in the world,
ai-snp3.7:26.3_0: having stayed under the heading of material pleasures,
ai-snp3.7:27.4_0: roars like a lion in the jungle.
ai-snp3.7:28.3_0: who would not be inspired by him,
ai-snp3.7:29.1_0: Those who wish may follow me;
ai-snp3.7:29.2_0: if he wishes to be permanent,
ai-snp3.7:29.3_0: Right here, I’ll go forth in the presence of him,
ai-snp3.7:29.4_0: this man of such splendid wisdom.”
ai-snp3.7:30.2_0: in the teaching of the Buddha,
ai-snp3.7:30.3_0: we’ll also go forth in the presence of him,
ai-snp3.7:30.4_0: this man of such splendid wisdom.”
ai-snp3.7:31.2_0: with joined palms held up, ask:
ai-snp3.7:32.3_0: it is visible, not subject to time,
ai-snp3.7:32.4_0: Here the going forth isn’t in vain
ai-snp3.7:32.5_0: for one who trains with diligence.”
ai-snp3.7:33.1_0: And the brahmin Sela together with his assembly received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
ai-snp3.7:33.2_0: And when the night had passed Keṇiya had a variety of delicious foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
ai-snp3.7:33.3_0: “Itʼs time, Master Gotama, the meal is ready.”
ai-snp3.7:33.4_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Keṇiya’s hermitage.
ai-snp3.7:33.4_1: and after approaching he sat down on the prepared seat, together with the Community of monks.
ai-snp3.7:34.1_0: Then Keṇiya served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-snp3.7:34.2_0: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Keṇiya took a low seat and sat to one side.
ai-snp3.7:34.3_0: The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
ai-snp3.7:35.1_0: “The foremost of sacrifices is offering to the sacred flame;
ai-snp3.7:35.3_0: A king is the best of humans,
ai-snp3.7:35.4_0: the ocean’s the foremost of rivers;
ai-snp3.7:36.1_0: The moon is the best in the night sky,
ai-snp3.7:36.2_0: the sun is the foremost of lights;
ai-snp3.7:36.3_0: But for those making offerings, desiring merit,
ai-snp3.7:36.4_0: The Sangha is indeed the best.”
ai-snp3.7:37.1_0: And the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
ai-snp3.7:37.2_0: Then Venerable Sela and his assembly, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path.
ai-snp3.7:37.3_0: And Venerable Sela together with his assembly became perfected.
ai-snp3.7:38.1_0: Then Sela with his assembly went to see the Buddha. He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:
ai-snp3.7:39.2_0: we went for refuge, O seer.
ai-snp3.7:39.3_0: In these seven days, Blessed One,
ai-snp3.7:39.4_0: we’ve become tamed in your teaching.
ai-snp3.7:40.1_0: You are the Buddha, you are the Teacher,
ai-snp3.7:40.2_0: You are the sages delighted by Māra.
ai-snp3.7:40.3_0: you have cut off the underlying tendencies,
ai-snp3.7:40.4_0: The grass blow on the top of the palm.
ai-snp3.7:41.3_0: by not grasping, you’re free of grasping.
ai-snp3.7:41.4_0: you’ve given up fear and dread.
ai-snp3.7:42.3_0: Stretch out your feet, great hero:
ai-snp3.7:42.4_0: let these giants worship the Teacher.”
